bibl.title: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Carl A. Grote, December 12, 1915

div1.p: Carter provides instructions for malaria prevention. He notes that the Rockefeller Foundation has shown interest in sponsoring a anti-malaria campaign.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Carl A. Grote, December 12, 1915
div1.opener:
OFFICE OF
MEDICAL OFFICER IN CHARGE
TREASURY DEPARTMENT
UNITED STATES
PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
BALTIMORE, MD. Dec 12/15
Dear Dr Grote:
div1.p:
I suspect that you have wondered why I have not
answered your letter of Nov 19.! I was in Porto Rico at the
time - and on that sick in hospital with Dengue, I have just
returned & will at least acknowledge it at once, although I
am not, it may be, prepared to answer it.

In my judgement, so far as I have data & time to form one there
there is only one method open open to us to control your Malaria in
- regard to the Malaria
Walker Co. that is at all feasible, viz. work from the end of
the human host, with protection of the man against
the access of the mosquito as an adjuvant, I do not think meas-
ures for the control of mosquito production are feasible.
Although I do not believe that there will ever be as
many again as there were last September

The work advised requires (A) sterilization of human
Carriers.

B20
2
Carriers, by Q which implies (I) determination of Carriers
(a) by blood examination or (by) by history: assuming that all who
had mal. fever last fall were carriers- Naturally (a) is far
the best method. (II) systematic exhibition of quinine to
such carriers until free from Parasites

If this be done completely the mosquitoes next summer
will have no source of infection - but it is a difficult thing
to get completely done. It is possible however & has been done

(B) The Cure of every person quo who by any chance
develops malarial fever next summer or fall, I say
Cure, meaning freeing from infection not simply
relieving present symptoms. This also is hard to have
done, from both physicians & patients, oppose one.

(C) In addition I would advise the use of Qui-
nine as a prophylactic - for all who live in the
malarial district. Koch's method 15 grams, per day
for on the 7th & 8th days from the last dose - (ie 2 doses every 8th
day) is probably preferable with the present price
of
3
of quinine - 6 gr. per day is probably better to me but
not much.

Theoretically if (A) & (B) are perfectly carried out (C) is
unnecessary, but it is extremely difficult to carry out
measures of this kind perfectly & I would strongly advise
the use of prophylactic quinine from about July 1June 17 to
say - Oct 1. This would for Koch's method be 25 doses of
15 grains each, for an adult- During July indeed the
interval might be made 10 instead of 8 days - making one less
dose.

The adjuvant, protection of man against the access of
mosquitoes, is screening & mosquito bars. People have
to be instructed in the use of both: shown not told, lots
of us are from Missouri, & shown many times. In some
houses this can be made a valuable adjuvant
inbut many the houses: are so open that screening can
not be used efficiently: mosquito bars can always be
used & do some good.

Now I want to tell you that the Rockefeller people have
under consideration a project of taking

BALTIMORE, MD.

two places in the South & trying out the very plan
I have here outlined. This work is to be done in conjunction
with this service. I do not know if think that they do not want
this talked of yet & will ask that you consider this confiden-
tial for the present. The Foundation would furnish
the Quinine: part of the expenses of the personnel.
They would furnish a carpenter to fit screens, etc. but
will not furnish material for screening, or mosquito
bars.

I missed my chance of being present at the last meet-
ing by being sick in San Juan & do not know, whether
they have definitely decided to go into this thing or
not. Nor do I know if they would consider that Walker County would be a suit-
able place for a demonstration. They would prefer a
place where malaria had long been a steady. I
mean where there were no great fluctuations in
number of cases. This has This is not the case with
5
Walker Co.. The best that I can do then is to send
your letter to van Ezdorf & to Kerr (in Wn) & see what they
think of it. It is not the class of place Dr. Rose contemplated.

This work would be done under the H.O. & he would have
to guarantee (as far as one can guarantee the action of
another man) the coöperation of the community &,
it would be “up to him” to get that coöperation from physi-
cians & laymen. Can you do this? No man, by allowable
means, could get the coöperation of the people in Jefferson
County on the Warrior.

If you think you can getso write to van Ezdorf at N. O.. To him
you can quote anything I have said, for I would be glad to
see this work done in Walker Co. (A) should be done be-
fore hot weather- Feb & March or April, would be a good
time - but up to-May- May 15 or even 15 days later isn't too late. I

If we can't help you, I hope we can, go to work yourself
on the lines indicated. If you can't do all indi-
cated- confine yourself to prophylactic quinine (C)
This ought to control malaria. Quinine ought
to be furnished at wholesale rates by the county

I did not mean to advise you to “confine yourself to pro-
phylactic Quinine”, The whole program is advisable.
What I meant was that even if you could not carry
out (A) & (B), that prophylactic Quinine (C) would give
you a pretty fair control.

Also preach mosquito bars & screening where
practicable show them how to use them-

The screening bulletins of this service are Nos 170. & 183
Von E;s is better for your purpose than mine. Prophy-
lactic Quinine is 175; & supplement no. 11 is also good St no 11: is also good is also good Koch's method
is better for you than Celli's I think - Q. is high.
div1.closer:
Very truly
your friend H. R. Carter You ought to be grateful for this letter I am dead tired
1/2 sick & very busy - yet it is a long &, I think, a fairly complete one
H. R. C.
